context: The institutional ethics committee of The Medical University of Warsaw approved the study. Written informed consent was obtained from the parent or guardian of each child included in the study. The recommendations of the CONSORT 2010 Statement for reporting parallel group randomized trials were followed. 17 We included children 3 to 18 years of age who were hospitalized at the Department of Pediatric Gastroenterology and Nutrition with H pylori infection confirmed with two of 3 tests: the 13C-urea breath test (UBT), histopathology (staining with haematoxylin and eosin, and with the Giemsa technique), or the rapid urease test from an antral biopsy. We excluded children who had received antibiotic treatment, proton pump inhibitor treatment, or both in the previous 4 weeks or who had received earlier eradication therapy. Eligible children were randomly assigned to receive: (1) a sequential treatment consisting of amoxicillin plus omeprazole for 5 days followed by a 5-day administration of clarithromycin plus tinidazole plus omeprazole; or (2) a 7-day, standard triple eradication therapy regimen consisting of 2 antibiotics (amoxicillin and clarithromycin) plus a proton pump inhibitor (omeprazole) followed by a 3-day administration of a placebo (lactose; Table I ). Each patient received a diary to record adverse events.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, urea is utilized as a key component in the 13C-urea breath test (UBT), which is a diagnostic tool for confirming H. pylori infection in children. The presence of urease produced by H. pylori hydrolyzes urea, leading to detectable changes in breath samples. This establishes a direct relationship between urea and the diagnosis of H. pylori infection.
